name: Final Stand
mana_cost: {1}{R}{W}{W}
text: Target creature gets +3/+3 and gains indestructible until end of turn. Destroy up to one other target creature with power less than that creature's power.
friedrich_miescher: This could go on a lot of commanders, but I imagine it being the most powerful on someone who is already a tank and has some ramp (or at least can draw cards). It's also possible that you don't want to destroy another creature since they might be able to remove it from combat. So if that's what your commander does, this spell isn't really ideal for them. But I'd try it out with someone like Rath or Oros anyway.
ǎn_tài_yīng: Not quite a final stand, but still pretty impressive! Giving a creature indestructible will let it live a lot longer in certain matchups. Also love that we get to play "Destroy one creature" with an enchantment. It doesn't take long for the board state to be unrecognizable and then this spell turns into 2-for-1 for

character: Quirk Singularity
color: U R
type: Enchantment
rarity: Mythic
<|gen_card|>
name: Nimbus of Genius
mana_cost: {2}{U/R}{U/R}
text: Players can't play lands or cast spells during their first turns. (This includes precombat main phases.) The same is true for turns after the player's first turn that don't have a full main phase, such as second and third turns. A spell that targets a player who has already finished all their turns this game may target any number of other players instead.
 suggen.name: Lucky Patch
 hint: This card is in the Commander deck Tatyova, Benthic Druid. You can try to find it there.
 galaxian: Gamma
 opinio: I really liked this mechanic when I tried it out with friends, and it seemed to work nicely. However, I didn't know how to make the effect fit into a Commander deck, so I just made an enchantment that does it. It may not be very fun in real games. Also, since this card doesn't say otherwise, you can still play lands and cast spells on your own turn if you want to.
 junky: N/A
 Miscellaneous:

<|startofcard|>
theme: Generic
character: All Might
color: W R
type: Legendary Creature - Human Hero
rarity: Mythic
<|gen_card|>
name: Sun-Hero, the Shielded
mana_cost: {4}{W}{R}
text: Double strike Whenever one or more tokens you control enter, creatures you control gain indestructible and get +X/+X until end of turn, where X is the number of tokens that entered.
pt: 3/4
 suggester: Lukas K.
 opin: I love the idea of a token-fueled "Sunbreaker" card! Not only do we have the iconic Sunbreaker Aura from the game's debut (which I can see being reprinted on this guy), but it also gives us another double striker in a deck like Aggro, which is always fun to play with. The only concern I had was if this card would feel too good without some kind of drawback (like a static tax on token creation, perhaps). But then I realized you can just make token-making artifacts or something.

At the beginning of combat on your turn, choose one — • Target creature gets +2/+0 until end of turn. • Create a 1/1 colorless Servo artifact creature token with defender. If you control another Servo, that token also has flying and first strike.
pt: 2/3
 opinion: I really like the idea of this card. The fact that he can't be blocked is pretty funny. But the abilities are weird, in my opinion. Sure, giving a creature +2/+0 at the beginning of combat is good, but only if there is an actual attacker. And creating a token with defender is interesting, but doesn't interact well with his ability to not be blocked, so you have to attack with him, even when you don't want to. I'm not sure how to make him better, though, since the flavor is pretty cool. Maybe give him flash? Or some

name: Doctor Octopus, Tentacles of Doom
mana_cost: {3}{U}
text: Whenever you cast a noncreature spell during your main phase, draw a card. {2}: Target creature you control gains "This creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step" until end of turn.
pt: 4/6
 suggester: Caleb James @ CJPlaytest
 suggestions: While the tentacle ability is a pretty simple effect on paper, there are a number of ways to exploit it in order to gain advantages against an opponent. The obvious one is attacking with creatures that don't untap, but if you can keep your non-untapping creatures on the board for multiple turns, they can do all sorts of things such as block every attack and attack through chump blocks without having to worry about being untapped at the end of their controller's untap step. Another possible use is to play a creature like Sutured Thrinax or Blisterstick Shaman and have it constantly untap and thus attack every turn. Of course, this will also leave your opponents with only a single blocker each combat, so they may still be

name: Fiery Confluence
mana_cost: {2}{R}
text: Choose two. This spell costs {1} less to cast for each different mode chosen this way. • Fiery Confluence deals 6 damage to any target. • Fiery Confluence deals 5 damage to any target and draws a card at random. • Fiery Confluence deals 4 damage to any target and adds three mana of any one color. • Fiery Confluence deals 3 damage to up to three targets.
 agreetag: http://magiccards.info/query?q=fiery+confluence&v=all
comments: Worth mentioning that this is not a cantrip. You don't draw a card for casting this, only for choosing the second or third mode. It is similar to Lightning Bolt in that it has several modes for one spell with different numbers of targets. Except the first mode doesn't have a limit on its number of targets (it could hit all creatures in play). Also, note that it can be used for card advantage when there are more than 8 creatures in play.

<|gen_card|>
name: Fiery Temper
mana_cost: {B}{R}
text: Target creature gets +2/+0 and gains trample until end of turn. Put a stun counter on that creature. (If a permanent with a stun counter would become untapped, remove one from it instead.)
 opinion: This card isn't as good as it looks at first glance. Sure, you get to pump your guy and give him trample. But he's also going to be stunned the next time he becomes tapped! That means he doesn't untap during his controller's next untap step. Which means you can't attack unless you have enough untappers for your team to keep the board full enough to avoid another round of stun counters. At best, this card will help you deal extra damage one time. The rest of the game will probably just go like normal.

<|gen_card|>
name: Kraven the Hunter
mana_cost: {2}{U}
text: When Kraven enters, exile up to two target nonland permanents. If you do, return those cards to the battlefield under your control at the beginning of the next end step. Whenever Kraven attacks, you may pay {2}. If you don't, tap him and put a stun counter on him. {T}: Remove all stun counters from Kraven. Put a +1/+1 counter on each creature target player controls that has a stun counter on it. Activate only as a sorcery.
pt: 2/3
 opinion: I have always loved Kraven, but this card is a joke, especially in Limited (not that I play much of that). It costs exactly what it does, so you have to choose between a good hunter and a bad one with no way to get them both. You can also sacrifice him for a free turn. The only way this could be better is if his ability activated during combat rather than after it ended.
comment: I like his artwork. It's a shame he's never been used again.

theme: Generic
character: Prominence Burn
color: R R
type: Sorcery
rarity: Rare
<|gen_card|>
name: Shards of Broken Glass
mana_cost: {2}{R}
text: Choose a creature type. Destroy each creature that isn't the chosen type and doesn't have protection from it. Those creatures can't be regenerated.
HECKLE // CHEER
 ninjutsu {1}{R} ({1}{R}, Return an unblocked attacker you control to hand: Put this card onto the battlefield from your hand tapped and attacking.) Whenever one or more permanents you control are destroyed, put a +1/+1 counter on each creature you control.
 opinion: For some reason, I love Ninja cards. They're fun, they can sneak around blocking creatures, and this is a pretty good one for a few reasons. Not only does it take out all creatures that aren't the chosen type or don't have protection from it (which could get annoying if you played this a lot against someone who was going for lots of +1/+1 counters), but then it gives those creatures counters! This seems like it might not matter too much since you'd probably rather play it when you've already got counters on your creatures

name: The Battle of Harrowing Peak
mana_cost: {1}{W/B}
text: (As this Saga enters and after your draw step, put a lore counter on it. Sacrifice after III.) I — Exile target creature card from a graveyard. II — Put a +1/+1 counter on each creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it. III — Each opponent loses X life, where X is the number of +1/+1 counters among creatures you control. Exile The Battle of Harrowing Peak.
multicolor_icon: W B
 opinion: This was spoiled in a Commander 2019 deck (Syr Aurelia). As usual, these cards are much stronger in commander than they are in standard. But even in a multiplayer EDH game, this would be too slow to really do anything meaningful by the time it finishes. If you're playing Syr Aurelia, this might be better than a lot of other three-card combos since it does things over multiple turns rather than all at once.

name: The Scorpion, Tyrannosaur King
mana_cost: {2}{B}{R}
text: Whenever you attack, if a creature died this turn, draw a card. {T}: Target creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn and can't be blocked this turn except by artifact creatures.
pt: 3/4
 opinions: This one has interesting flavor and good synergy with the mechanic introduced in the Spider-Man games. There are so many ways to make your opponent lose life that it's almost always worth attacking even if you're going to get killed. But even if you never attack, drawing cards off the extra damage is pretty good too. I'd rate him an 8/10, but I only like him because he's from the Spider-Man games.

name: Dr. Octopus
mana_cost: {3}{B}
text: Tap two untapped creatures you control: Regenerate Dr. Octopus. Whenever one or more non-Human creatures you control attack, if at least three of them are attacking, draw a card.
pt: 2/4
 atmosphere: Ominous
ಠ_ಠ: This is a little weird. You can regenerate Dr. Octopus twice for the price of tapping any two other creatures, but those don't have to be on the battlefield. That makes this guy not much better than a cheap villain with regeneration...except when it comes time to pay for that second regeneration! At that point you have the choice of spending your second regeneration or just paying life equal to Dr. Octopus's toughness. But there's also the third possibility: pay 4 life and sacrifice him. I like that, as it's always an interesting dilemma.

name: Hanta Sero, Earth Guardian
mana_cost: {2}{G}{W}
text: When Hanta Sero enters, you may exile another target legendary creature card from your graveyard. If you do, create a 3/3 green and white Spirit creature token with flying. Vigilance (Attacking doesn't cause this creature to tap.) Whenever Hanta Sero deals combat damage to a player or planeswalker, create a 1/1 colorless Spirit creature token that's tapped and attacking that player or planeswalker.
pt: 4/5
område: Amonkhet
ename: Hanta Sero, Earth Guardian
maker: David Lee
 opinion: There are many ways to build decks around Hanta Sero, and if it survives a few turns you'll be creating quite a few tokens. It's worth remembering that the ability triggers on combat damage assignment — not when Hanta Sero leaves combat.
 assumption: I was originally planning on putting this in a deck with Cavalier of Night and Dawn, but then I realized you can put both cards in a Standard format deck.
 comment:

 atmos: This is a very rare and beautiful old enchantment, originally called "Mishra's Rulebook." It was made legal at the same time the rulebook itself changed to prevent people from casting multiple spells in a single turn. It doesn't look like it belongs on this card, though!
  name: Mishra's Rulebook

text: At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice this enchantment unless you pay {3}. If you do, draw a card. Each player may cast only one spell during each of their turns. Cards named Mishra's Rulebook can't enter your hand from anywhere.
 opin: What would you rather have? This or all the artifact lands? I know which I prefer.
colec: Psionic Art

TDM Notes: The card is just fine as-is, but there's a ton of potential for her abilities to interact with each other in unpredictable ways. If she was the commander of a deck, it might be fun to design a deck that makes use of those synergies, like making sure all your creatures are at least 3 toughness and using the drawback from the first ability to power through that.

 suggestion: With an artifact and two land cards in hand, play Dragon’s Hoard, a legendary Dragon artifact that draws cards when you play Dragons. Partner it with Red Dragon, Shou Zi. name: Temporal Isolation
mana_cost: {1}{U}
text: Tap target permanent. Put a stun counter on it. (If a permanent with a stun counter would become untapped, remove one from it instead.) When that permanent leaves the battlefield this turn, put a time counter on it.
 opinion: This is basically a Temporal Isolation that makes the creature untap after a few turns. It's pretty solid for only one mana, even if you don't get your money back right away. And hey, it's an instant!

 opinon: I love the flashback mechanic, but I wish they didn't add counters to everything.

name: Thrashing Bramble
mana_cost: {1}{G}{U}
text: You may exile a creature card from your hand rather than pay this spell's mana cost. Draw two cards.
̈
name: Deeproot Waterfall
mana_cost: {4}{G}{U}
text: Scry 2, then draw two cards. Flashback {5}{G}{U} (You may cast this card from your graveyard for its flashback cost. Then exile it.)
comments: As it turns out, scrying before you draw is pretty good. The best use of the flashback cost is to exile this to your hand with a Gloomhaven character or two in hand and have a guaranteed turn-one Thrashing Bramble draw two. You can also do this with a Fable deck that's missing its fabled creatures, which I guess are kind of like Gloomhaven characters.
comments: I actually do think Deeproot Waterfall is strong enough without the additional flashback cost, and that part mostly just adds to the hilarity of playing a game where you're trying to flashback a card you already drew

name: Tidus, Zanmato Striker

text: Partner with Yuna, Warrior of the Dawn (When this creature enters, target player may put Yuna into their hand from their library, then shuffle.) When Tidus enters, create a 3/1 white Knight creature token. Whenever another creature you control dies, draw a card.
pt: 3/3
multicolor: W U
 opinioñs: Tidus is really good with his partner Yuna, who can be played straight from your deck for free thanks to him entering alongside her. That means that if you draft Tidus and want to play with him, you're basically playing a deck with two less cards. But that's okay! You can use all those mana resources on other things. Just don't forget about him at the end of the game when he's still out there, or your opponents might get a little bit mad at you.

@Trapster. I'm not quite sure how to play it yet, but you could start out with just a token that says "Whenever you cast a spell, if it has flashback, you may pay {R}. If you do, exile it. At the beginning of your end step, if there are three or more cards in your graveyard that have flashback, you win the game." The thing is, you can just play it like a regular deck by putting all the spells you want on the stack and waiting until you cast the last one before sacrificing the token.

name: Shimmering Creek
mana_cost: 
text: This land enters tapped. {T}: Add {G}. {1}{G}, {T}: Search your library for a basic land card, put it onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle.

- Shimmering Creek is basically just a Borderland with a cycling ability tacked on. It's only notable as one of the few common lands that enters untapped.
- I like this card because I have a hard time getting around the cycling cost (mostly because I don't like to discard cards). I think this is a decent card in any green deck. If you could discard at instant speed, it might even be great.
- This isn't the best card in the world, but it has the advantage of coming into play untapped and it cycles. Cycling lets you search for a land and tap it without putting it into your hand or paying mana to cast it. That's useful if you need a land to block or activate an ability on an artifact or creature.
- Shimmering Creek is a Borderland that can cycle for one green mana. It's
